email.subject: [ACPI] Linux/ACPI mailing list move -- re-subscribe is necessary
email.body:
Please note that acpi-devel@lists.sourceforge.net is defunct.
The new list to use for Linux/ACPI topics is linux-acpi@vger.kernel.org
If you'd like to participate in Linux/ACPI development and support discussions, you can subscribe here: http://vger.kernel.org/vger-lists.html#linux-acpi
Or read the archives here: http://dir.gmane.org/gmane.linux.acpi.devel http://www.mail-archive.com/linux-acpi%40vger.kernel.org/ http://marc.theaimsgroup.com/?l=linux-acpi&r=1&w=2
thanks, -Len

email.subject: [ACPI] ACPI list change - you must re-subscribe
email.body:
Everybody,
Sourceforge reliability is (way) down (again), and spam is up. In contrast, LKML and linux-ia64 on vger.kernel.org run quite well.
The folks at vger.kernel.org have graciously agreed to host our list for us. Given the current sourceforge instability, I'd like to transition immediately.
There will be no more messages to acpi-devel@lists.sourceforge.net (except reminders like this:-)
Please subscribe to linux-acpi@vger.kernel.org per the notes below.
thanks, -Len Brown, Intel Open Source Technology Center
E-mail lists related to Linux ACPI and Power Management (1/4/2006)
linux-acpi@vger.kernel.org Description: Linux/ACPI Development, Discussion, Support Subscribe: mailto:majordomo@vger.kernel.org?body=subscribe linux-acpi http://vger.kernel.org/vger-lists.html#linux-acpi Note that no human approves subscriptions -- if you can't get your FROM: header to agree with your address then you can't subscribe. Archives for linux-acpi@vger.kernel.org http://marc.theaimsgroup.com/?l=linux-acpi&r=1&w=2 (requested) http://news.gmane.org/gmane.linux.acpi.devel (includes old sourceforge archive too) http://www.mail-archive.com (requested, but not yet operational as of 1/4/06) Archives for acpi-devel@lists.sourceforge.net (discontinued Jan 2006): http://sourceforge.net/mailarchive/forum.php?forum=acpi-devel http://marc.theaimsgroup.com/?l=acpi4linux http://news.gmane.org/gmane.linux.acpi.devel Archives for acpi-support@lists.sourceforge.net (discontinued Feb 2004) http://sourceforge.net/mailarchive/forum.php?forum=acpi-support
linux-acpi@intel.com Description: Includes Len Brown and the other Intel folks who work with Linux/ACPI. Use this list to bug Intel directly about Linux/ACPI. This is used by some distros to cc: Intel on bugzilla entries when acpi-bugzilla@lists.sourceforge.net would not work. (note that linux-acpi@intel.com is subscribed to linux-acpi@vger.kernel.org, so there is no need to cross post)
acpi-bugzilla@lists.sourceforge.net Description: Used only for cc: on public Linux/ACPI bug reports Subscribe if you want to see bugzilla updates in real-time. Do not post to this list Archives: http://sourceforge.net/mailarchive/forum.php?forum=acpi-bugzilla http://www.mail-archive.com/acpi-bugzilla%40lists.sourceforge.net/ Subscribe: mailto:acpi-bugzilla-request@lists.sourceforge.net?subject=subscribe http://lists.sourceforge.net/lists/listinfo/acpi-bugzilla
linux-pm@lists.osdl.org Description: General discussion about power management issues under Linux Subscribe: https://lists.osdl.org/mailman/listinfo/linux-pm Archives: http://lists.osdl.org/pipermail/linux-pm/
linux-pm-devel@lists.sourceforge.net Description: General discussion about power management issues under Linux Subscribe: http://lists.sourceforge.net/lists/listinfo/linux-pm-devel Archives: http://sourceforge.net/mailarchive/forum.php?forum=linux-pm-devel Comment: seems to have the same charter as the more heavily used OSDL list above.
------------------------------------------------------- This SF.net email is sponsored by: Splunk Inc. Do you grep through log files for problems? Stop! email.subject: [ACPI] Linux/ACPI mailing list move -- re-subscribe is necessary
email.body:
Please note that acpi-devel@lists.sourceforge.net is defunct. It will carry no new messages (except reminders like this:-)
The new list is linux-acpi@vger.kernel.org To subscribe, go here: http://vger.kernel.org/vger-lists.html#linux-acpi
thanks, -Len Brown, Intel Open Source Technology Center
E-mail lists related to Linux ACPI and Power Management (1/16/2005)
linux-acpi@vger.kernel.org Description: Linux/ACPI Development, Discussion, Support Subscribe: mailto:majordomo@vger.kernel.org?body=subscribe linux-acpi http://vger.kernel.org/vger-lists.html#linux-acpi Note that your "From:" address must match your subscription address, or you will not be able to subscribe. Archives for linux-acpi (started Jan 2006) http://marc.theaimsgroup.com/?l=linux-acpi&r=1&w=2 http://dir.gmane.org/gmane.linux.acpi.devel http://www.mail-archive.com/linux-acpi@vger.kernel.org/ Archives for acpi-devel@lists.sourceforge.net (discontinued Jan 2006): http://sourceforge.net/mailarchive/forum.php?forum=acpi-devel http://marc.theaimsgroup.com/?l=acpi4linux http://news.gmane.org/gmane.linux.acpi.devel Archives for acpi-support@lists.sourceforge.net (discontinued Feb 2004) http://sourceforge.net/mailarchive/forum.php?forum=acpi-support
intel-linux-acpi@linux.intel.com Description: Intel-only sub-set of above - used to ping Intel team directly.
acpi-bugzilla@lists.sourceforge.net Description: Used only for cc: on public Linux/ACPI bug reports Subscribe if you want to see bugzilla updates in real-time. Do not post to this list Archives: http://sourceforge.net/mailarchive/forum.php?forum=acpi-bugzilla http://www.mail-archive.com/acpi-bugzilla%40lists.sourceforge.net/ Subscribe: mailto:acpi-bugzilla-request@lists.sourceforge.net?subject=subscribe http://lists.sourceforge.net/lists/listinfo/acpi-bugzilla
linux-pm@lists.osdl.org Description: General discussion about power management issues under Linux Subscribe: https://lists.osdl.org/mailman/listinfo/linux-pm Archives: http://lists.osdl.org/pipermail/linux-pm/
linux-pm-devel@lists.sourceforge.net Description: General discussion about power management issues under Linux Subscribe: http://lists.sourceforge.net/lists/listinfo/linux-pm-devel Archives: http://sourceforge.net/mailarchive/forum.php?forum=linux-pm-devel Comment: seems to have the same charter as the more heavily used OSDL list above.
